speaker: User
message: Hi PERSON_FIRSTNAME_2

speaker: User
message: Hi PERSON_FIRSTNAME_2, I like to ask how to in-text cite a definition from a journal article?

speaker: User
message: This is the passage that I'd like to cite, According to PERSON_LASTNAME_4 (2013), stress is defined as a "state of disharmony in the bodys homeostasis when a real or perceived threat is encountered".

speaker: User
message: Would this be the correct way?

speaker: User
message: As I am taking a direct definition..

speaker: User
message: Yes

speaker: Help Desk
message: You would need to include the page number or paragraph number for those without page number

speaker: User
message: As Crane (2017) said,"Mindfulness has become a trend word conveying a diversity of understandings dependent on context" (p. 586).

speaker: User
message: If no page number, you can use paragraph number -(para.8).

speaker: User
message: so if its paragraph it would be, According to PERSON_LASTNAME_4 (2013), stress is defined as a "state of disharmony in the bodys homeostasis when a real or perceived threat is encountered" (para.2).

speaker: User
message: do I also include the dash (-)?

speaker: User
message: No need dash.

speaker: User
message: Alright then! Thank you so much~

speaker: User
message: Yes, I'm also citing another definition, but it is from a website that has no paragraph or page number

speaker: User
message: it looks like this..

speaker: User
message: What should I put if not page or para number?

speaker: User
message: Hmm let me take a look.

speaker: User
message: Hang on.

speaker: User
message: Ok.

speaker: User
message: Generally for website, if there is no paragraph number, we can use section and header

speaker: User
message: however, in this case, it seems more like a search result

speaker: User
message: yeahh..

speaker: User
message: So this is a little out of the normal. haha.

speaker: User
message: I am considering using either the NCI search results as the section header. But let me discuss this with my colleague first so that we can provide the more appropriate suggestion.

speaker: User
message: So if you could hang on a moment.

speaker: User
message: Hi PERSON_FIRSTNAME_1, may I get back to you via email? Let me check with the APA citation book.

speaker: User
message: Sure no problem, in that case I'll wait for your response through my email!

speaker: User
message: Ok. This is what my colleague and I think may be approriate

speaker: User
message: Perhaps you can use "Social Support" as the section header

speaker: User
message: And may I suggest using this page instead?

speaker: User
message: It is the same definition and on the same website

speaker: User
message: You can use the section header "social support"

speaker: User
message: It is more appropriate as compare to citing from the search result.

speaker: User
message: example of how to cite using section header

speaker: User
message: PERSON_LASTNAME_6, 2019, Emergencies section).

speaker: User
message: If there is no author?

speaker: User
message: Would this PERSON_LASTNAME_6, 2019, Emergencies section) be placed towards the end?

speaker: Help Desk
message: In this case, the organisation, National Cancer Institute, can be regard as the author

speaker: Help Desk
message: You can do it either way

speaker: Help Desk
message: Similar to your PERSON_LASTNAME_4

speaker: Help Desk
message: if you are using narrative in-text citation, (which is what you did for PERSON_LASTNAME_4 , you can put the section at the end of the definition

speaker: User
message: The National Cancer Institute (2018) defines social support as a network of family, friends, and other members that are available in times of need to give psychological, physical, and financial help (section).

speaker: User
message: Yup

speaker: Help Desk
message: Or you can also do Social support is defined as "a network of family, friends, and other members that are available in times of need to give psychological, physical, and financial help" (National Cancer Institute, 2018, Social support section)
